instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-28-50A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

Hi have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - 820-28-50A, that has green light, but no fan spin and only pulls 0.040A from the bench PSU.

All big coils are 0V, and on diode mode I get:

L7630 = 0.0194V
L 8920 = 0.0057V

Are those shorted or are they low tension?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-28-50A no power
threads.message:
Both values look good.

Check the basic voltages/signals from power on sequence.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-28-50A no power
threads.message:
Hi again,

I get

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> =0v

<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>5V3V3_REG_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.56v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5v
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_VBST</SIGNAL> =4.5v
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_VFB</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_ENTRIP</SIGNAL> = 0V

Do you think that it is <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>? If so, where can I get it in other board model (don't have any other 1286 board)?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-28-50A no power
threads.message:
Don't go so fast for <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> first?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-28-50A no power
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-28-50A no power
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).
If present, check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-28-50A no power
threads.message: I have a drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> but no pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> (steady 0V).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-28-50A no power
threads.message:
Then is something related with PCH.
Check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> and RTC signals.
